awd_titl_txt: Transcriptional Regulation of Secondary Cell Wall Biosynthesis
awd_abstract_narration: Secondary walls are the major constituent of tracheary elements and fibers (types of plant cells) in wood, and constitute most abundant biomass produced by plants. Understanding the molecular mechanisms that regulate the switching on and off the genes (a process called transcription) needed for secondary wall biosynthesis during wood formation is a critical issue in plant biology and will have important implications in biofuel production. It was recently discovered that the secondary wall-associated NAC domain of the transcription factor SND1 (a protein that regulates transcription) is a master switch activating the developmental program of secondary wall biosynthesis. The current hypothesis is that SND1 together with its downstream transcription factors exert combinatorial transcriptional regulation of secondary wall biosynthetic genes. The aim of this project is to unravel this combinatorial transcriptional regulatory program by identification of direct targets of SND1 downstream transcription factors and investigation of the developmental switches controlling SND1 expression. The project outcomes will provide a comprehensive picture of how the concerted actions of multilayered transcriptional switches result in the activation of the secondary wall biosynthetic program. The proposed work will contribute to the understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying wood formation, which will potentially provide valuable tools for genetically improving the quality and quantity of wood, the most important raw materials for traditional forest products and potentially for biofuel production. The project will also involve the training of graduate and undergraduate students and its outcomes will be disseminated in a timely fashion to enhance the understanding of plant biology research and its benefits to society.

por.por_cntn:
Secondary walls are the major constituent of tracheary elements and fibers in wood, which is the most abundant biomass produced by plants. Understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying the transcriptional regulation of secondary wall biosynthesis during wood formation is a critical issue in plant biology and will have important implications in biofuel production. It was recently discovered that the secondary wall-associated NAC domain transcription factor SND1 is a master switch activating the developmental program of secondary wall biosynthesis. The current hypothesis is that SND1 together with their downstream transcription factors exert combinatorial transcriptional regulation of secondary wall biosynthetic genes. The aim of this project is to unravel this combinatorial transcriptional regulatory program by identification of direct targets of SND1 downstream transcription factors and investigation of target gene functions.

Our study of Arabidopsis secondary wall NAC (SWN) master switches have revealed that the regulation of secondary wall biosynthesis in vessels involves 7 functionally redundant SWNs, whereas 3 functionally redundant SWNs control secondary wall biosynthesis in fibers. We also found that the vessel-specific and fiber-specific SWNs all bind to the same cis-elements, SNBEs, thereby leading to the activation of the secondary wall biosynthetic program. Our study of Arabidopsis SND1 direct targets has revealed MYB46 and MYB83 function as the second-level master switches controlling secondary wall biosynthesis and they bind to the cis-element, SMRE, to activate their direct targets. We have identified and functionally characterized a group of SND1 orthologs and their downstream targets in poplar, rice, maize and switchgrass for their roles in regulating secondary wall biosynthesis. We have also discovered two new SND1-regulated downstream genes involved in regulating secondary wall biosynthesis. These findings have not only enriched our understanding of the molecular mechanisms controlling transcriptional regulation of wood formation but also provided useful tools for genetic modification of biomass production in biofuel crops.

Three research associates and four graduate students received training in molecular biology and genetics by participating in the study of transcriptional regulation of secondary wall biosynthesis. Ten undergraduate students were trained by graduate students to perform molecular characterization of transcription factors controlling secondary wall biosynthesis and two of them were co-authored in a paper. Most of undergraduate students went on to continue their study in medical schools. The research findings were disseminated timely through publications in professional journals; we have published 13 research articles under the support of this NSF grant. The findings from this NSF-funded research were also presented in six invited talks at the meetings and universities.
